entry.title: RTR Cutover Tasks and Data Validations during Go-Live
entry.content:
RTR Cutover Tasks and Data Validations during Go-Live:

(GenAI Assisted Content created based on Personal Experience)

 

  • Introduction of RTR Overall Cutover Task:

During a Go-Live Cutover for SAP Finance (FI), data validation is a critical activity to ensure that all migrated and newly created financial data is accurate, complete, and ready for business operations in the new SAP system. Below is a summary of key data validation activities and best practices during Go-Live cutover in SAP Finance:

Key SAP Finance Data Validations During Go-Live Cutover

  1. Master Data Validation
  • General Ledger (GL) Accounts: Verify all GL accounts are created, with correct account types, descriptions, and assignments.
  • Vendor & Customer Master: Check all vendor/customer details (name, address, payment terms, bank details, recon accounts).
  • Asset Master: Confirm all assets are transferred with correct values, depreciation terms, asset class, cost center assignment.
  • Bank Master Data: Validate bank accounts, bank keys, and related information.
  1. Open Item Validation
  • AP/AR Open Items: Ensure all open items in Accounts Payable and Receivable are migrated correctly, with right document numbers, amounts, due dates, and assignments.
  • GL Open Items: Check open GL items are migrated and reconciled to legacy system balances.
  1. Balances Validation
  • GL Balances: Validate period-end and year-end closing balances for all GL accounts.
  • AP/AR Balances: Reconcile vendor/customer balances between SAP and legacy system.
  • Asset Balances: Confirm asset values and accumulated depreciation match legacy system.
  1. Transactional Data Validation
  • Journal Entries: Ensure all migrated journal entries are complete and accurate.
  • Documents Posting: Test posting new documents to ensure system configuration is correct.
  • Document Numbers: Verify document number ranges and sequences.
  1. Configuration & Controls Validation
  • Tax Codes: Validate correct tax codes, rates, and assignments.
  • Payment Terms & Methods: Check that payment terms and methods are correctly set up.
  • Reconciliation Accounts: Confirm recon accounts are correctly assigned to vendors/customers.
  • Posting Periods: Ensure correct posting periods are open/closed as per cutover plan.
  1. Reporting Validation
  • Run standard SAP FI reports (e.g., trial balance, balance sheet, vendor/customer balances, asset reports) and compare with legacy system reports.
  • Validate custom reports if applicable.
  1. User Acceptance Testing (UAT) & Approval
  • Users review and sign-off on sample data, balances, and reports.
  • Document approval and exception handling process.
  1. Interfaces & Integration Validation
  • Validate data flow to/from other modules (MM, SD, Asset Accounting) and external systems (bank interfaces, tax authorities).

Cutover Data Validation Checklist (Sample)

Validation Type

Activity

Responsible

GL Master Data

Check all GL accounts & attributes

FI Lead

Vendor Master Data

Verify vendor details & recon accounts

AP Team

Customer Master Data

Validate customer info & recon accounts

AR Team

AP Open Items

Reconcile open AP items

FI/AP Team

AR Open Items

Reconcile open AR items

FI/AR Team

GL Balances

Match closing balances with legacy system

FI Lead

Asset Balances

Confirm asset values and depreciation

Asset Team

Tax Codes

Verify tax code setup

FI Lead

Document Posting

Test postings in SAP

FI Team

Reporting

Run and validate SAP reports

FI Team

Best Practices

  • Plan for multiple rounds of validation: Ideally, run validations during mock cutovers before the actual go-live.
  • Document every validation step and result for audit and compliance.
  • Assign clear ownership for each validation activity.
  • Resolve all discrepancies before final cutover sign-off.
  • Communicate findings and actions to stakeholders regularly.

 

  • Loading Trial Balance in SAP During Cutover

Loading the Trial Balance into SAP during the cutover is a key activity to ensure that the opening balances in the new SAP system match those from the legacy system. This process usually involves uploading balances into General Ledger (GL) accounts as of the cutover date (e.g., opening balance at the start of the fiscal period).

Below is a step-by-step guideline for loading the Trial Balance into SAP FI:

  1. Preparation
  2. Extract Trial Balance from Legacy System
  • Export the final, reconciled trial balance as of the cutover date (usually period end).
  • Ensure balances are mapped to SAP GL accounts.
  1. Data Mapping
  • Map legacy GL accounts to SAP GL account numbers.
  • Ensure company codes, profit centers, cost centers, and other dimensions are mapped.
  1. File Preparation
  • Prepare the data for upload in a required format (usually Excel or CSV).
  • Typical fields: Company Code, Fiscal Year, Period, GL Account, Amount, Debit/Credit indicator, Profit Center, Cost Center (if applicable).
  1. Loading Methods in SAP

You can use several methods to upload Trial Balance data into SAP:

  1. Direct Entry via Transaction Code F-02 (Manual Entry)
  • Use T-code F-02 (Enter GL Account Posting).
  • Enter each GL account opening balance as a line item.
  • This is feasible only for small trial balances.

**B. Batch Input / LSMW (Legacy System Migration Workbench)

  • Use LSMW or Batch Input to mass upload data.
  • Steps:
    1. Create an LSMW project for GL postings (usually using object: 0100, method: 0000, program: RFBIBL00).
    2. Prepare the data file in the format required by the program.
    3. Upload and process the file, generating batch input sessions.
    4. Run the batch input session to post documents.

**C. SAP Standard Program: RFBIBL00 (Batch Input for Accounting Documents)

  • This is a popular method for mass upload.
  • Download the sample file template for RFBIBL00 from SAP.
  • Populate your trial balance data.
  • Upload the file using transaction SM35 (Batch Input) or via LSMW.

**D. SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit

  • For S/4HANA systems, use the Migration Cockpit to upload opening balances.
  • Use the "FI - GL Account Balances" migration object.
  1. Posting to SAP
  • The upload process typically posts to a special document type (e.g., ‘SA’) with a reference indicating ‘Opening Balance’.
  • Postings are made to the first open period in SAP (e.g., period 1 of the fiscal year).
  1. Validation and Reconciliation

After loading:

  • Run SAP reports (e.g., F.01 – Financial Statement, S_ALR_87012277 – GL Account Balances) to verify balances.
  • Reconcile SAP Trial Balance with the legacy trial balance.
  • Investigate and resolve any discrepancies.
  1. Documentation
  • Document the process, mappings, and validations.
  • Keep audit trails of uploaded files, posting documents, and reconciliation results.

Sample Data File Format (for RFBIBL00 or LSMW)

Company Code

Fiscal Year

Period

GL Account

Amount

D/C Indicator

Text

Profit Center

Cost Center

1000

2025

01

400000

150,000

D

Opening Bal.

1100

2100

1000

2025

01

200000

150,000

C

Opening Bal.

1200

2200

Tips and Best Practices

  • Post only opening balances, not individual transactions.
  • Ensure all balances are posted for the correct fiscal period and company code.
  • Review posting logs and error reports after the upload.
  • Get business and finance team sign-off after reconciliation.
  • Keep documentation for audit and compliance.

 

 

  • Open GR or IR wrt Purchase Orders Load:

Loading Open GR (Goods Receipt) and Open IR (Invoice Receipt) with reference to purchase orders from the legacy system during SAP cutover is an essential step to ensure the transition to SAP is seamless and your procurement processes remain accurate.

Below is a practical, step-by-step guide to help you understand and execute this process:

How to Load Open GR and Open IR During Cutover in SAP

  1. What Are Open GR and Open IR?
  • Open GR: Goods have been received against a PO in legacy, but the invoice is not yet posted.
  • Open IR: Invoice has been received against a PO, but the goods have not yet been received, or sometimes the invoice is posted but payment not yet made.
  • Both must be migrated to SAP to reflect correct PO status, inventory, and liabilities.
  1. Data Preparation
  2. Extract Data from Legacy System
  • List all open POs with pending GRs (where goods have been received but invoice not posted) and open IRs (where invoice received but goods not yet received or invoice posted but payment not made).
  • Capture key details: PO number, item, quantity, value, vendor, material, plant, etc.
  1. Map Legacy Data to SAP Structure
  • Map legacy PO numbers to SAP PO numbers (if numbers change).
  • Ensure material, plant, vendor codes match SAP master data.
  1. Loading Open GR (Goods Receipt) in SAP
  2. Using Transaction MB01/MIGO with Movement Type 101 (Goods Receipt for PO)
  1. Create Goods Receipt (GR):
    • Transaction: MIGO (or MB01 in ECC)
    • Reference: Purchase Order
    • Movement Type: 101
    • Enter quantity and value as per open GR in legacy.
    • Post the GR document.
  2. Repeat for all open GRs.
    • Ensure the posting date matches the legacy GR date (if possible).
  3. Result:
    • Inventory updated in SAP.
    • PO history updated with GR.
    • Accounting entries posted.
  1. Mass Upload Method
  • For many open GRs, use LSMW or BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE for automated upload.
  1. Loading Open IR (Invoice Receipt) in SAP
  2. Using Transaction MIRO (Enter Incoming Invoice)
  1. Create Invoice Receipt (IR):
    • Transaction: MIRO
    • Reference: Purchase Order
    • Enter invoice number, quantity, value, vendor, and other relevant details.
    • Post the IR document.
  2. Repeat for all open IRs.
    • Make sure to use correct document/invoice dates.
  3. Result:
    • Vendor liability updated in SAP.
    • PO history updated with IR.
    • Accounting entries posted.
  1. Mass Upload Method
  • For large volumes, use LSMW or BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_CREATE for automated upload.
  1. Recommendations & Best Practices
  • Sequence: Always upload open GRs before open IRs to maintain correct PO history and avoid system errors.
  • Reconciliation: After upload, reconcile PO histories, inventory, and vendor liabilities in SAP with legacy balances.
  • Document Mapping: Retain references to legacy document numbers for traceability.
  • Testing: Try the process in a quality/test system before production cutover.
  • Audit Trail: Document all uploads and reconciliations for audit purposes.
  1. Sample Data Structure for Upload

Open GR (MIGO/MB01):

PO Number

PO Item

Material

Plant

Quantity

Value

Posting Date

450000123

10

MAT001

1000

50

5,000

2025-09-25

Open IR (MIRO):

PO Number

PO Item

Invoice No

Vendor

Quantity

Value

Invoice Date

450000123

10

INV-789

VEND01

50

5,000

2025-09-25

Summary Table

Activity

Transaction

Movement Type

Reference

Automation Option

Open GR

MIGO/MB01

101

PO

LSMW, BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE

Open IR

MIRO

N/A

PO

LSMW, BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_CREATE

 

  • Open Deliveries with respect to Sales Orders:

Loading Open Deliveries with respect to Sales Orders during SAP cutover is crucial to ensure your order fulfillment and billing processes continue seamlessly after go-live.

Below is a practical, step-by-step guide for loading open deliveries in SAP SD during cutover:

How to Load Open Deliveries with respect to Sales Orders During Cutover

  1. Understand the Business Scenario
  • Open Deliveries = Deliveries created in the legacy system for sales orders, but goods issue (GI) has not yet been posted, or billing not yet done.
  • You need to recreate these deliveries in SAP so you can post GI and invoice them after go-live, reflecting the correct order status and inventory position.
  1. Data Preparation
  2. Extract Data from Legacy System
  • List all open deliveries and their corresponding sales orders.
  • Key details: Sales order number, item, delivery number, delivery quantity, material, plant, shipping point, delivery date, customer, etc.
  1. Map Data to SAP Structure
  • Ensure legacy sales orders, materials, customers, shipping points, and plants are mapped to SAP master data.
  • If delivery numbers change, maintain legacy reference for audit.
  1. Loading Open Deliveries in SAP
  2. Manual Creation (For Small Volumes)
  1. Create Delivery:
    • Transaction: VL01N (Create Outbound Delivery with Order Reference)
    • Enter the sales order number and shipping point.
    • Enter delivery quantity and other relevant details.
    • Save the delivery.
  2. Repeat for each open delivery.
  1. Mass Upload (For Large Volumes)
  • Use LSMW (Legacy System Migration Workbench), BAPI_OUTB_DELIVERY_CREATE_SLS, or custom ABAP programs to automate delivery creation.

LSMW Approach:

  • Object: Standard Batch/Direct Input for Deliveries or use BAPI.
  • Prepare upload file with all required fields: sales order, item, quantity, shipping point, delivery date, etc.

BAPI Approach:

  • Use BAPI_OUTB_DELIVERY_CREATE_SLS to create outbound deliveries programmatically.
  1. Post Cutover Activities
  • After deliveries are loaded, you can process further actions:
    • Goods Issue Posting: Transaction VL02N (Change Outbound Delivery) to post GI when the goods are shipped.
    • Billing: After GI, process invoice (VF01).
  1. Validation and Reconciliation
  • Reconcile open deliveries in SAP with the legacy system list.
  • Check delivery status, quantities, and dates.
  • Ensure no duplicate or missing deliveries.
  • Validate that the inventory position is correct.
  1. Best Practices
  • Sequence: Ensure open sales orders are loaded before deliveries.
  • Testing: Perform the process in a test system before production cutover.
  • Audit Trail: Retain legacy delivery numbers for reference in custom fields or SAP texts.
  • Communication: Coordinate with warehouse/logistics and order management teams.

Sample Upload Data Structure

Sales Order

Order Item

Delivery Qty

Material

Plant

Shipping Point

Delivery Date

Customer

500000123

10

100

MAT001

1100

SH01

2025-09-25

100001

Summary Table

Activity

Transaction / Method

Reference

Automation Option

Open Delivery Creation

VL01N / LSMW / BAPI

Sales Order

LSMW, BAPI_OUTB_DELIVERY_CREATE_SLS

Goods Issue Posting

VL02N

Outbound Delivery

 

Invoice Creation

VF01

Outbound Delivery

 

 

  • Inventory GL Balance Load Method:

Loading Inventory GL balances during SAP cutover is a critical step that must be handled carefully to ensure both financial accuracy and proper integration with the Materials Management (MM) module. Below is a clear, step-by-step guide on how to load Inventory GL balances during cutover in SAP:

  1. Understand the Business Scenario
  • Inventory balances represent the value of stock on hand as per your legacy system.
  • In SAP, inventory values should match both the FI GL balances and the MM stock quantities.
  1. Preparation
  2. Extract Inventory Balances from Legacy System
  • Obtain inventory account balances (GL) as of cutover date.
  • Obtain inventory quantities and values by material, plant, and storage location if using MM module.
  1. Data Mapping
  • Map legacy inventory GL accounts to SAP GL accounts.
  • Map materials, plants, storage locations if uploading to MM.
  1. Loading Methods
  2. If Using SAP FI Only (GL Level, No MM Integration)
  • Use LSMW or Batch Input (RFBIBL00) to post opening balances to inventory GL accounts.
  • This method only updates FI and does not create stock in MM.

Steps:

  1. Prepare upload file with company code, fiscal year, period, inventory GL account, amount, debit/credit indicator, text.
  2. Use LSMW or RFBIBL00 to upload as a normal GL posting (document type 'SA' or 'OB').
  3. Reconcile total inventory balance in SAP FI with legacy system.
  1. If Using SAP FI-MM Integration (Standard Approach)

Best Practice:
Always create initial stock in SAP MM (using transaction code MB1C or MIGO) so that both MM and FI are updated. This ensures proper valuation and future reconciliation.

Steps:

  1. Create Initial Stock (MM):
    • Use transaction MB1C or MIGO with movement type 561 ("Initial entry of stock balances").
    • Enter material number, quantity, plant, storage location, and value.
    • The system automatically posts inventory value to the inventory GL account via automatic account determination.
  2. Result:
    • MM stock quantities are created.
    • FI is updated with inventory balance in the correct GL account.
  3. Reconciliation:
    • Run inventory valuation reports (e.g., MB5B, MB52) to check MM stock.
    • Run FAGLB03 or FS10N to check GL balances.
    • Reconcile between MM and FI.
  1. Validation and Sign-Off
  • Compare SAP inventory balances (FI and MM) with legacy system.
  • Investigate and resolve any discrepancies.
  • Obtain sign-off from both Finance and Inventory teams.
  1. Documentation
  • Document process, mappings, posting documents, and reconciliation results for audit purposes.

Sample Upload File for MM Initial Stock (MB1C, Movement Type 561)

Material

Plant

Storage Location

Quantity

Value per Unit

Total Value

MAT001

1000

SLOC01

500

10

5,000

FI Posting Generated Automatically:

GL Account

Amount

D/C Indicator

Text

140000

5,000

D

Initial Stock

Tips & Best Practices

  • Always load stock via MM if you are using inventory management; do not post directly to inventory GL in FI for stock that should be managed in MM.
  • Check automatic account determination in SAP (transaction OBYC) to ensure postings go to correct inventory GL.
  • Test in a QA system before production cutover.
  • Ensure quantities and values match between MM and FI.

 

  • Running standard cost calculation after Inventory initial load with legacy Standard Price:

Running standard cost calculation before any logistics transactions or goods movements are posted during SAP Go-Live cutover is a vital step, especially for organizations implementing Standard Costing in SAP CO-PC (Product Costing) and MM.

Here’s a clear, step-by-step guideline for this process:

Why Run Standard Cost Calculation Before Logistics Transactions?

  • Ensures accurate inventory valuation: All incoming goods (stock) during initial postings and after go-live will be valued at the correct standard cost.
  • Prevents valuation inconsistencies: If goods movements (e.g., GR, GI) are posted before standard costs are set, inventory can be valued at zero or incorrect rates.
  • Enables proper cost control and profitability analysis.

Step-by-Step: Standard Cost Calculation During Cutover

  1. Pre-requisites
  • All relevant master data (materials, BOM, routings, work centers, cost centers, activity rates) are loaded and validated in SAP.
  • All costing variants, costing versions, and valuation strategies are set up.
  • No goods movements or logistics transactions have been posted yet.
  1. Standard Cost Estimate Run
  2. Run Cost Estimate for Materials
  • Transaction Code: CK11N (Create Material Cost Estimate)
  • Select the relevant materials/plants and run the cost estimate.
  • Review detailed cost components: raw materials, labor, overhead, etc.
  1. Mark the Cost Estimates
  • Transaction Code: CK24 (Mark and Release Cost Estimates)
  • Mark the cost estimates for the desired costing version and period.
  1. Release the Cost Estimates
  • Still in CK24, release the marked cost estimates.
  • This action updates the material master (accounting view) with the new standard price (field: Standard Price, typically field VPRS in S/4HANA, STPRS in ECC).
  1. Validation
  • Check material master data (MM03) to confirm standard price is updated.
  • Run relevant reports (e.g., CK13N – Display Material Cost Estimate, CK40N – Mass Processing of Cost Estimates).
  1. Proceed with Logistics Transactions
  • Only after standard cost estimates are released, begin posting goods receipts, initial stock uploads (MB1C/MIGO with movement type 561), or other logistics transactions.
  • This ensures all inventory postings are valued at the correct standard cost.

Best Practices

  • Do not post any goods movements before standard costs are released.
  • Reconcile and validate costing results before release.
  • Communicate clearly with business teams and cutover managers regarding the sequence.
  • Document all steps for compliance and audit.

Process Flow Summary

  1. Load master data (materials, BOMs, routings, etc.)
  2. Run standard cost estimates (CK11N/CK40N)
  3. Mark and release standard costs (CK24)
  4. Validate standard prices on material master
  5. Post initial stocks/goods movements (MB1C/MIGO)
  6. Continue with other logistics and financial transactions

entry.title: Re: PRD: Unable to convert UTC timezone to specific Timezone
entry.content:
@Julie_Davis_Wyn here is a screen shot of where you need to add it :

rf.preffered_timezone you can take with the following join. It will find the preferred time zone of report executor(admins):

left Join PA_USER_PREFERENCE rf --Preference TimeZone per user Table
on rf.user_id=(select top 1 owner from PA_REPORT_JOB ORDER BY last_update_timestamp DESC) and rf.USER_TYPE='A'

Because when you run query in PRD or SQL workbench it always read the regional settings of your computer and try to show the data in timezone from our windows setting.

entry.title: Dynamic Pictures (Headers/Footers) on Document Generation Template (SF Employee Central)
entry.content:
Dear All,

I recently worked on a use‐case in Employee Central’s document generation tool where the client needed dynamic headers, footers, and signatures to vary based on the legal entity. The twist? The documents must remain in the same format across entities.

After researching blogs, troubleshooting, and consulting an SAP expert, I landed on a solution that allows the system to automatically insert the correct logo or image when an employee generates a document. Below is how it works:(After 2505 Release)

SOLUTION:

Step 1: Insert all your Images into a single Document Template (For e.g. for Header you can create a Header template and save all your header images in Header Template, similarly for Footer you can create another template with naming Footer and save all your Footer images into that Template):

There are two options available for inserting all your images into a single document template

Option A: Drag and drop the image to the Template

  • Save the images into your local drive
  • Drop or Simply Copy & paste the image into the document generation template.
  • Select that particular image and click the additional options (three dots) from the menu.
  • From the menu, choose Insert/edit Image.
  • Copy the Source URL (e.g., data: image/jpeg; base64, XXXXXXXXXXXX) that is generated when an image is dropped.
  • Save the template.

Option B: Insert the link to add image to the template (Preferred Option)

  • Click on the three dots of the editor from the menu.
  • Select Insert/Edit Image

  • Add the image URL (You can raise a ticket with SAP to host the images into SAP/SF Server to generate a URL of the images)

  • Set description (if required) and adjust the dimensions
  • Click Ok and save the template.

Step 2: Create Letter Content and Insert the Image Placeholder in Next/Another New Template:

  • In this template, you can insert your content along with image placeholders.
  • Open another new document template where you want to insert the image
  • Click the additional options (three dots) menu again.
  • Select Insert/Edit Image.
  • Type the placeholder only in Source URL. (For ex. [[Header]])
  • Set the Dimensions

  • Click on OK and Save the template (Once the template saved, URL will auto generate)
  • Post Save, the template will look something like below

Step 3: Write the Business Rule:

  • Go to Configure Business Rule Configuration section & create a rule with a scenario: Document Generation Template Mapping Rule and Select Object 1 as “Job Information”

  • Choose your if conditions (based on client requirement) and set your then condition. In Set condition map the copied Source URL (the link generated in Step 1), similar way we can write if else statement.
  • Save the business rule.

Step 4: Assign Rule to Placeholder:

  • Navigate to Manage Document Template Mapping.
  • Search for that particular Document Template created in Step 2
  • Assign the business rule to the corresponding placeholder[[Header]] or [[Footer]] in the template.

 

CONCLUSION:

So, at last, I’ve been able to deliver dynamic headers and footers to meet customer expectations.

Now — what did you think of this post? Were the concepts clear? I’d love to hear your feedback or questions in the comments.”

entry.title: SAC seamless planning: Model design principles - compared to SAP BW
entry.content:
After years of developing planning solutions with SAP BW Integrated Planning and BPC, I recently completed a SAC Planning project with seamless planning. Coming from a BW IP/BPC background, I initially tried to replicate familiar structures in SAC. But I quickly realized that SAC’s flexibility requires a different mindset, starting with model design and granularity.

In this first blog post, I’ll share model design decisions, and practical tips for BW developers moving to SAC Planning. This blog post shall also help developers without BW background by highlighting the restrictions of certain functionalities in SAC. Finally, I also want to show you the potential additional value of seamless planning for your planning project.

1. SAC vs. SAP BW modelling: general background information

In SAC, the new model is a mixture of InfoCube-like and a direct-update planning ADSO in BW. All characteristics are keys (InfoCube-like), but there is only an active table (direct-update). Furthermore, measures in SAC models cannot be of a text/characteristic type. So,

  • there are no requests, no chance to roll back
  • no inherited delta mechanism
  • no characteristic as key figure.

But SAC models come with a Standard data audit functionality, that works out of the box (except for import jobs). Because of the missing requests in SAC, planning functions should be kept simple.

2. Model Design: SAC is not BW

When designing planning solutions in SAC, I recommend you to break down planning requirements across multiple models. In SAP BW, developers were required to create composite providers and aggregation levels (and input enabled queries) on top of ADSOs to structure planning logic. SAC does not have those intermediate layers, which can accelerate development. But this simplicity also introduces challenges when trying to consolidate everything into a single model.

Here are a few examples:

  • Any data entry creates an edit version. If multiple planning scenarios share one model, SAC shows the “Publish Data” banner across all stories when you edit plan data in one story.

  • The SAC Excel Add-In allows end users to plan on ad-hoc created tables, which can be convenient for flexibility. However, this becomes significantly more critical when SAC models are large and complex. In such cases, ad-hoc planning can bypass frontend validations (for instance, javascript logic in stories), leading to inconsistencies and governance challenges (check comments here Ability to disable planning option in SAC Cloud excel add-in centrally by admin).
  • Upload jobs in SAC cannot derive master data automatically. In huge models, this often leads to wide files with many columns.
  • Data validations are less robust than characteristic relationships in BW. They must be handled manually in Data Actions and carefully considered during story design, since SAC still allows "unassigned" values even when validations are defined.
  • Data point comments are more fragile. Because they depend on the full navigation state, they can be lost more easily in huge models.

These limitations highlight the need to rethink model design. Instead of treating an SAC planning model like a BW ADSO, it’s more accurate to compare it to an aggregation level or even an input enabled query. It's a layer tailored to specific planning logic.

3. How does seamless planning help?

Seamless planning let's you expose your fact and dimension tables to Datasphere. Hence, you can bring together the data of your different models more easily for reporting purposes instead of having a lot of cross model copies in native SAC.

You can also

  • add SQLscript logic,
  • enrich your plan data with Datasphere tables for configuration/customizing (multiple keys and characteristics as non-key fields),
  • or leveraging public dimensions exposed from SAC (single key).

The results can be consumed

  • via real-time reporting (Datasphere Analytic Models)
  • or via import jobs to SAC models.

4. What's next?

With the Q4/2025 update, seamless planning shall become bidirectional, meaning that the View data in Datasphere can be added to SAC models as read-only version. This update will make Datasphere data better accessible. It will support direct consumption of Datasphere fact data in planning models, which will let you have a single planning enabled table with real-time reference data from other planning models.

Summary

  • Model design matters: Avoid putting all planning scenarios into one model. SAC lacks BW’s aggregation layer, so splitting models improves performance and governance. 
  • Seamless Planning currently focuses on exposing SAC fact and dimension tables to SAP Datasphere, enabling integrated reporting and SQLScript-based logic. It will help you implementing a federated planning landscape in SAC.
  • Always keep the Roadmap in mind: By Q4/2025, SAC will support direct consumption of Datasphere fact data in planning models, reducing reliance on import jobs and enabling real-time integration in planning enabled crosstabs.

entry.title: Re: Experience with UPA
entry.content:
Hi,

I've worked with UPA on a SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation where UPA has been made mandatory by SAP, indicating that it is viewed as a best practice for future implementations. UPA effectively addresses limitations in ledger functionality and the availability of multiple currencies defined in FI configuration across the SAP S/4HANA landscape.

For SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud and On-Premise customers, UPA has been available since the 2022 release, with significant enhancements introduced in the 2023 release. In existing systems, retroactive activation requires a migration process and adherence to stringent prerequisites, which are only supported starting from the 2023 release. Notably, only the US and DE localizations are currently supported.

For new SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud or On-Premise implementations, I strongly recommend a thorough evaluation of UPA activation, keeping in mind the limitations outlined in the 3191636 - Universal Parallel Accounting: Scope Information. 

Best regards,
Jonathan

entry.title: The Power of One: How Unified SAP Joule Boosts AI Adoption (a technical sight)
entry.content:
Short read. Big pictures.

What is ‘Unified SAP Joule’? One Joule for all SAP solutions, independent of the underlying tech stacks. (End users know ‘SAP,’ not SFSF/S4/BS, etc.)

Why unify? Better user acceptance → better adoption. If users don’t accept it, they won’t adopt it.

How to get there? Use the SAP IAM Reference Architecture for SAP Joule as the backbone, following down below:

 

1) Overview

Everything SAP‑labeled shows up to the corporate IAM/IdP as SAP Cloud Identity (SCI). Inside the SAP domain, identities & authorizations are unified so the landscape can be SAP‑managed later. User management, role/group assignment, and authentication all go through SAP Cloud Identity Services.

 

2) Common Data Model (CDM)

At design time – when activating SAP Joule, each business solution (e.g., S/4HANA) exposes its Joule capabilities via CDM. Joule functions map to business roles; CDM content is deployed to SAP Build Work Zone (WZ); Roles defined in CDM appear as roles in Content Manager.
E.g. S4 HANA Capability <-> S/4 HANA Business Role <-> CDM role <-> Role in WZ <-> Capability in WZ.
Given that, SAP Joule knows at DT what authorizations a user need for which capability.

 

3) Sync of Authorizations

Roles/groups and identity assignments from business solution (S/4 HANA, SuccessFactors, …) synchronize into Work Zone. Synchronizing groups and assignments into SCI are optional today and may become required if WZ polls SCI. Third‑party IAM can assign groups to users via SCI; Work Zone’s user store is independent of XSUAA.

 

4) Sync of Identities

Identities flow through SCIM to your identity management, centrally governed across SAP. The Global Unique User Identifier is synchronized from SCI into the business solutions.

 

5) Authentication Flow

All authentication goes through SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS), enabling principal propagation behind the scenes (later more). This is the basis for Unified SAP Joule and prepares the path for SAP‑managed connectivity when new services are subscribed.

 

6) Example: End‑to‑End Authentication

  1. User opens Joule.
  2. Joule asks IAS to authenticate user; Optional: IAS forwards authentication to Corporate IdP and enriches token with IAS information (GUUID) after authentication (identity federation).
  3. User is authenticated to use Joule while Joule knows, which capabilities the user is allowed to use.
  4. User is calling a Joule capability (e.g. Create leave request).
  5. Joule asks IAS for a token for this specific identity for the business solution of the capability to be called.
  6. IAS is handing out the token.
  7. Joule can authenticate as the user to the business solution (principal propagation).
  8. Joule calling the function module inside the business solution in the name of the user.

This shows the importance that all solutions and the BTP within this scenario trust the same authentication instance (IAS).

 

7) 3rd‑Party Identity Management (where it fits)

  • Identity sources: SFSF (internals), Fieldglass (externals), or AD.
  • Synchronization of users between SFSF and SCI.
  • GUUID is written back to SFSF.
  • Groups originate in SaaS solutions and show as SCI groups can sync to 3rd-party IAM.
  • S/4 HANA roles can sync to 3rd‑party IAM.
  • Management split:
    • BTP & SaaS via SCI.
    • S/4 HANA via IAM directly plus GUUID provisioning:
      • IAM reads from SCI and provisions to S/4 HANA, or
      • SCI reads from S/4 HANA and writes back UserID+GUUID only;
      • Both option align with the reference architecture.

 

Final thought

Unify identity and auth once → unlock Joule everywhere. Less friction. More adoption. Happier users. 🎯

entry.title: Consuming Events from SAP Advanced Event Mesh with the Event AddOn for ERP and/or AIFAEM
entry.content:
Introduction

There are multiple ways to connect an SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) Broker to your S/4HANA or ECC System.

  1. Enterprise Event Enablement (IWXBE) via AMQP --> see this Blog
  2. Event Add On for ERP via REST
  3. Custom REST Service

In this Blog I will shortly introduce you to Approaches 2 and 3. Details can be found in the Github Repository. 

Defining Outbound Events is quite simple. Somewhere in the System an event is happening. The Event Enablement Solution just has to push the Event to the Event Broker, possibly with some additional Data. Defining Inbound Events on the opposite obviously depends on the event payload. If it is a Notification Event which is relevant for this consuming system, an API has to be called to fetch more data to be processed. To make it simple, in this Blog we assume the consumed Event is a Data Event, containing all data required to process the Event. Also in that case the processing of the event highly depends on the event structure. That is why coding is inevitable, regardless of the chosen Event Enablement solution (RAP, Event AddOn for ERP, AIFAEM).

The only way to avoid custom coding in the ECC or S/4HANA System is the consumption of the Event using the AEM Adapter of BTP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration. Here it is possible to map the Event to a Payload which can be processed by a Standard API provided by the ECC / S/4HANA System. 

In this Blog I show you how you can extend the EventAddOn Approach with AIFAEM both for Monitoring & Mapping only or for Monitoring, Mapping and Processing in AIF. Also there is the possibility to create a custom REST Service to pass the message to AIF directly. In both cases the AEM REST Delivery Point (RDP) SetUp is not part of the Blog. If you want to know how to set up a RDP, feel free to check out this Blog. Here we simulate the RDP by API Client Bruno.

 

Event Add On for ERP via REST + AIFAEM

The SAP Event Add-on for ERP is a great Tool, which makes it easy to push custom Events from your ECC or S/4HANA System to SAP Integration Suite, advanced Event Mesh (AEM) based on a low code/no code approach. For the consumption of Events, the AddOn offers a pre delivered SICF Service, where Endpoints for every Inbound Event can be customized. These Endpoints have to be called from a REST Delivery Point on AEM. 

The whole set up (among a lot of other helpful material) is available in this Mission in the SAP Discovery Center.

Additional to the Event Addon I have set up two scenarios which add the AIF component to the Event AddOn. 

1) Mapping and Monitoring in AIF, Processing in IDoc Process Code Function Module

Request:

 

Result in Event AddOn Monitor

Idoc Monitoring

AIF Monitoring

2) Mapping, Monitoring & Processing in AIF Action

Request:

 

Result:

IDoc Monitor

 

AIF Error Monitoring

HowTo and Development Artifacts see here

 

Custom REST Service & AIFAEM

AIFAEM offers the licence Part (all interfaces which are connected with AEM are included in the AEM licence) and Development Artifacts like DDIC Types (Cloud Event Header) and an Action to push Outbound Events to AEM. For Inbound Events there is no pre delivered connector, so it is necessary to create a custom HTTP Handler Class and SICF Node to pass the Events to AIF. I have decided to provide only one endpoint and the interface determination happens based on the Topic Header and a regular expression maintained in an AIF Value Mapping. 

In my Github Repository I provide a class and other configurations you can take over and adapt to your needs.

Request:

Result in AIF Error Monitoring:

 

HowTo and Development Artifacts see here

 

Summary

With SAP Integration Suite, advanced Event Mesh, Cloud Integration, RAP, the Event AddOn for ERP and AIFAEM we have a lot of options, which even can be combined to fit to your requirements and skillset. This Blog shows how the EventAddOn and AIF can be combined or AIFAEM can be used with a custom REST Service.
